metadata.title: Recent Advances in Stretchable Supercapacitors Enabled by Low‐Dimensional Nanomaterials

sections.text:

review www.small-journal.com
Recent Advances in Stretchable Supercapacitors Enabled by Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials
Changyong Cao,* Yihang Chu, Yihao Zhou, Chi Zhang, and Shaoxing Qu
Prof. C. Cao, Y. Chu Laboratory for Soft Machines & Electronics School of Packaging Michigan State University East Lansing, MI 48824, USA E-mail: ccao@msu.edu Prof. C. Cao Department of Mechanical Engineering Michigan State University East Lansing, MI 48824, USA Prof. C. Cao, Y. Chu Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering Michigan State University East Lansing, MI 48824, USA
DOI: 10.1002/smll.201803976
wearable devices,[1,2] sensitive robotic skin,[3] electronic papers,[4] soft surgical tools,[5] electronic imaging devices,[5] in vivo health monitors,[3] as well as various collapsible gadgets[6] has attracted widespread attention upon flexible and stretchable electronics with a combination of advanced electrical performance with robust mechanical properties such as stretchability, foldability, twistability, flexibility, and durability.[7,8] In particular, device stretchability is highly desirable for wearable electronics due to the inevitable deformation (strain) generated in human skin and human body activity. As essential components of stretchable electronics systems, energy conversion and storage devices should be capable of sustaining their performance when subjected to the large strains that may be experienced by the highly stretchable electronics in various applications. The consistency of stretchability in both electronics and energy devices becomes the key to the successful integration of a combined self-powered stretchable system in wearable electronics applications. To date, significant effort and progress have
been made in developing stretchable energy devices such as batteries, supercapacitors (SCs), and solar cells.[9–13] Although batteries are typically favored among power sources for electronic devices due to their superior power density and energy
Supercapacitors (SCs) have shown great potential for mobile energy storage technology owing to their long-term durability, electrochemical stability, structural simplicity, as well as exceptional power density without much compromise in the energy density and cycle life parameters. As a result, stretchable SC devices have been incorporated in a variety of emerging electronics applications ranging from wearable electronic textiles to microrobots to integrated energy systems. In this review, the recent progress and achievements in the field of stretchable SCs enabled by low-dimensional nanomaterials such as polypyrrole, carbon nanotubes, and graphene are presented. First, the three major categories of stretchable supercapacitors are discussed: double-layer supercapacitors, pseudo-supercapacitors, and hybrid supercapacitors. Then, the representative progress in developing stretchable electrodes with low-dimensional (0D, 1D, and 2D) nanomaterials is described. Next, the design strategies enabling the stretchability of the devices, including the wavy-shape design, wire-shape design, textile-shape design, kirigami-shape design, origami-shape design, and serpentine bridgeisland design are emphasized, with the aim of improving the electrochemical performance under the complex stretchability conditions that may be encountered in practical applications. Finally, the newest developments, major challenges, and outlook in the field of stretchable SC development and manufacturing are discussed.
Stretchable Supercapacitors

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Over the last decade, the increasing demand for integrating innovative electronics for a broad range of applications like

1803976 (2 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
density, SCs have shown great potential for mobile energy storage technology due to their long-term durability, electrochemical stability, structural simplicity, as well as exceptional power density and cycle efficiency.[14–17] Furthermore, taking into account the ubiquitous emphasis on sustainability, environmental-friendliness, and efficiency in pursuit of fossil fuel conservation and carbon footprint minimization, the superiority of SCs in such aspects renders them the most prominent alternative and complementary counterpart to batteries in developing flexible/stretchable energy storage devices.[13,18] As a result, different types of stretchable SC devices have been proposed and incorporated in a variety of emerging electronics applications ranging from wearable electronics[19] to microrobots[20] to integrated energy systems.[15,21–23]
To achieve high-performance stretchable SCs, significant effort has been taken to develop novel electrode materials, electrolytes, and optimal device designs over the years. Generally, stretchable SC electrode materials are required to have high specific capacitance, large rate capability, and high cycle stability.[24] Among the variety of materials, low-dimensional nanomaterials such as transition metal oxide nanoparticles, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, MoS2, and MXene have rapidly become superior candidates for stretchable electrodes due to their remarkable physical and electrical properties like excellent conductivity, good stability, and mechanical flexibility.[17,25–28] For instance, nanomaterial electrodes enable higher specific capacitance for SCs because of their enhanced surface area. In addition, mechanically and chemically stable electrode materials should be employed for developing stretchable SCs capable of cycle stability. Furthermore, due to the dependence of specific capacitance and rate capability on electronic and ionic conductivity, it is desirable to get a high electronic and ionic conductivity by precise control of pore size and prudent design of the electrodes so as to maintain the rectangular shape of cyclic voltammetry curves and the symmetricity of galvanostatic charging–discharging curves. With the limited stretchability of most available materials for electrodes, electrolytes, and packaging components,[22] most current researches focus on the improvement of device performance through the innovation of novel electrode and electrolyte materials combining stable electrochemical performance with desired mechanical properties, alongside creative structure designs for enhanced deformability and retained electrochemical parameters.[29,30]
In this review, we comprehensively examine the recent advances in stretchable SCs enabled by low-dimensional nanomaterials such as 0D nanoparticles, 1D nanotubes and nanowires,[31] as well as 2D graphene[26] and transition metal dichalcogenides[25] with a variety of design strategies (Figure 1). We have summarized the most important aspects of stretchable SCs ranging from novel materials to structural design strategies to device integration, and discussed the major challenges faced by each. The content of the review is organized as follows: First, we categorize the major stretchable SC designs which have emerged to prominence in recent studies. This is followed by a detailed summary of the advances and achievements in employing low-dimensional materials and their nanocomposites in stretchable SCs. Afterward, we briefly describe the major design strategies for fabricating stretchable SCs, as well as the

sections.heading: 2. Categories of Stretchable Supercapacitors
sections.text: SCs can be generally classified into three types based on their storage mechanism: the electrochemical double layer capacitors (EDLCs), pseudocapacitors, and hybrid capacitors combining electrostatic capacitance and pseudocapacitance. The development and advancement for each type of stretchable SCs are briefly reviewed in this section.

sections.heading: 2.1. Stretchable Double Layer SCs
sections.text:
EDLCs are usually operated through the adsorption of charged ions for electrodes possessing differing polarities within the electrolyte to generate electric double layers for electrical energy storage.[32,33] Carbon-based materials including carbon nanotubes,[34–36] graphene,[37] onion-like carbon, and activated carbon[38] have become the most common materials utilized for EDLC electrodes due to their high surface area, exceptional conductivity, as well as good compatibility with multiple strategies to achieve stretchability. As shown in Figure 2a, a stretchable
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (4 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
electrode of SC was made of buckled single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) film that was transferred onto a prestretched polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) substrate. The formed wrinkled structures (Figure 2b,c) enabled the SCs to be highly stretchable without sacrificing electrochemical performance, demonstrating nearly ideal capacitive behavior for EDLCs, in which cyclic voltammograms (CV) curves showed a rectangular shape even under high scan rates (Figure 2d).[39] The initial specific capacitance of the device possessed the minimum value of 50–100 F g−1, and was maintained without reduction in the electrochemical performance under an applied strain of 30%, indicating its good electrochemical stability.[39] Besides SWCNTs, other carbon-based materials like graphene have been used in stretchable EDLCs. For instance, Zang et al. developed highly stretchable SCs with crumpled-graphene-paper (CG-paper) as electrodes (Figure 2e,f).[40] The stretchable electrodes were fabricated through the transferring of CG-paper to a prestrained elastomer film. The as-fabricated SCs equipped with CG-paper electrodes and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)/H3PO4 gel electrolyte exhibited unprecedented stretchability with linear and areal strains respectively attaining 300% and 800%, as well as an exceptional specific capacitance of 196 F g−1, which exhibited little deterioration after 1000 stretch/release cycles up to 200% strain.[40]
In addition, highly stretchable EDLCs were also fabricated by a chemical vapor deposited (CVD) graphene film that was dry-transferred onto an elastomeric (PDMS) substrate. The SC devices demonstrated near-ideal quasirectangular CV curves with scan rates from 0.05 to 1 V s−1 and the areal capacitance of them can reach up to 5.8 µF cm−2 with 50% transparency.[41] More importantly, the electrochemical performance of the stretchable graphene EDLCs was almost identical under different strains from 0% to 40%, demonstrated by the CV curves and the calculated specific capacitance curves. While stretchable EDLCs have been successfully demonstrated with different carbon materials, the vital drawbacks of these doublelayer devices are their inferior specific capacitances and low energy densities, although amelioration may be possible through the addition of high-performance active materials.

sections.heading: 2.2. Stretchable Pseudo-Supercapacitors
sections.text:
In contrast to the low energy density and inferior capacitance of EDLCs made of carbon materials, the specific capacitance (Csp) values of stretchable pseudo-supercapacitors (PSCs) are generally far superior due to the involved surface redox reactions.[42] Thus, stretchable PSCs possess the potential to exceed EDLCs in energy density with relatively high power density.[43,44] However, the incorporation of pseudocapacitive active materials in the typical powder state within stretchable designs while maintaining ideal electrical and mechanical properties has proven to be far more difficult to implement than more common designs involving carbon-based materials. Generally, CNTs or graphene are used as scaffolds to obtain the mechanical integrity. However, the small loading of the pseudocapacitive materials limits the energy density obtained from such kinds of stretchable SCs. One possible solution to bypass the limitation of insufficient loading for pseudocapacitive active materials
is to fabricate all-solid-state sandwich-like stretchable PSCs. As shown in Figure 3a, a sandwich-like structure for a stretchable PSC made of CNT-MnO2/functionalized carbon nanotubeCNT (FCNT-CNT) demonstrated excellent mechanical stability, with high electrochemical performance retention after 10 000 stretch–release cycles of up to 100% strain (Figure 3b,c).[44,45] Meanwhile, their impressive energy density (≈30 W h kg−1) and power density (≈32 kW kg−1) also exceeded those of comparable EDLCs with CNT film and PSCs from graphene, demonstrating the potential of stretchable PSCs in achieving superior energy density while maintaining good mechanical stability.[45]
As an alternative, conductive polymers such as polyaniline (PANI), polythiophene, and polypyrrole (PPy) have been used for fabricating PSC electrodes.[22,46–49] Particularly, PANI has received special attention due to its superior specific capacitance, cost-effectiveness, ease-of-use, and favorable stability performance.[34,50] Studies have shown that low-dimensional nanomaterials with nanostructured PANI, including nanorods, nanotubes, and nanospheres, have yielded superior capacitive performance in comparison with pure PANI and similar carbonaceous counterparts.[34,46,50] For example, stretchable electrodes employing SWCNT/PANI composite films on pre-elongated elastomers demonstrated decent specific capacitances up to 435 F g−1 (Figure 3d–h).[51] Through a combination of the excellent coupling at SWCNT/PANI interfaces, the refinement of porosity to minimize the possibility of cracking and the employment of a solid, fortified electrolyte penetration structure, the device performance could be maintained even after 1000 cycles of elongation to a strain of 120%, and a maximum elongation of 140% was recorded (Figure 3i,j).

sections.heading: 2.3. Stretchable Hybrid Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Stretchable hybrid SCs (HSCs) are those based on the utilization of electrodes possessing contrasting properties, such that one demonstrates electrostatic capacitance and the other demonstrates pseudocapacitance capacitance.[52] In general, HSCs are asymmetric,[53] combining a high-capacitance faradaic pseudocapacitance electrode for improved energy density and a non-faradaic double-layer capacitance electrode for enhanced power density.[54] In this regard, Gu and Wei[55] developed all-solid-state asymmetric SCs with superior energy density by incorporating wrinkled MnO2/CNT hybrid positive electrodes and wrinkled Fe2O3/CNT composite negative electrodes with a neutral Na2SO4/PVA gel electrolyte (Figure 4a–c). The optimal HSCs demonstrated reverse cycling in the voltage window between 0 and 2 V (Figure 4d) and excellent energy density of 45.8 Wh kg−1 at the power density of 0.41 kW kg−1 (Figure 4f). As shown in Figure 4e, this device also exhibited remarkable mechanical durability and electrochemical stability, with a 98.9% retainment of its initial specific capacitance after 10 000 electrochemical cycles over various strains. Therefore, stretchable HSC devices are a promising choice for future applications with the requirements of exceptional electrochemical performance, extended potential window, and compounded capabilities of the two electrodes operating in tandem.

sections.heading: 3.1. 0D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
0D nanomaterials are spherical particles that have three dimensions limited to the nanoscale range of 1–100 nm. Such 0D nanoparticles possess unique properties due to their quantum confinement and large surface area which may result in drastic reduction of flexural rigidity for fabricated devices.[8,56] There are three types of 0D nanomaterials: solid nanoparticles, hollow nanoparticles, and core–shell nanoparticles.[24] Although solid nanoparticles, such as carbon nanospheres and transition metal oxides (e.g., MnO2), have been intensively studied for designing supercapacitor electrodes,[57] hollow nanoparticles are promising materials for SC electrodes due to their properties of low density, high surface-to-volume ratio, and shortened pathways for transportation of mass and charge.[58] Even greater performance for SC applications can be achieved with multishelled nanoparticles.[59] As for the core–shell nanoparticles that are formed by combining faradaic and non-faradaic materials, they possess advantages such as improved electrical conductivity, less agglomeration, robust chemical and mechanical stability, etc.[24] For example, the electrodes from PPy-coated Lycra fabric (Figure 5a,b) could retain the overwhelming majority of the initial electrochemical performance after 1000 stretching cycles, while an increase in specific capacitance from 108.5 to 125.1 F g−1 was recorded with increasing elongation from 0% to 60% (Figure 5c).[47] However, a major drawback of the nanoparticle-based SC is the delamination of the active nanoparticles after long term charge/discharge cycles. To solve this problem, Yun et al. presented a PPycoated MnO2 nanoparticles/CNT textile stretchable SC with improved capacitance retention (Figure 5d–h).[48] The PPyMnO2 CNT textile SC exhibited a superior electrochemical performance with energy density of 31.1 Wh kg−1 and power density of 22.1 kW kg−1 compared with one counterpart without PPy coating.[48] More than 90% capacitance could remain after 10 000 charge/discharge cycles (Figure 5f,g).

Additionally, the SCs were able to survive under a strain of up to 20% and light up a green light-emitting diode (LED) when subjected to different stretching strains (Figure 5e,h). The superior electrochemical properties of the PPy-MnO2 CNT textile SCs provided an effective strategy to achieve high performance stretchable SCs with 0D nanomaterials using thin conductive polymer coatings.

sections.heading: 3.2. 1D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
1D nanomaterials such as nanorods, nanowires, and nanotubes have been extensively investigated for making flexible or stretchable SC electrodes due to their distinctive and remarkable physical and electrochemical properties.[30,33,60,61] For example, Thomas and co-workers reported a facile method called spinon nanoimprinting to produce highly ordered carbon nanopillars as supercapacitor electrodes.[62] The specific capacitance of the carbon nanopillar arrays (diameter ≈95 nm and height ≈200 nm) was 3.4 mF cm−2, which is a remarkable improvement in comparison to that of a planar carbon film (0.05 mF cm−2). The low possibility of the individual nanorod/ nanopillar to collapse on to its neighboring structures enables them more accessible to the electrolyte, leading to increased ionic conductivity. Meanwhile, nanowires have been widely used for electrodes due to their high-aspect-ratio, which can offer large surface area to store charges and an efficient pathway
to transport charges. In a demonstration, Chen and co-workers fabricated a kind of editable stretchable SC based on MnO2 nanowires and CNTs with the fabrication process shown in Figure 6a,b.[63] As a 1D nanostructured pseudocapacitive material, MnO2 nanowires have higher theoretical capacitance and thus are able to enhance the energy density of SCs. In brief, a gel electrolyte based on PVA was coated on two electrodes to produce malleable SCs similar to paper which could be easily molded into custom configurations and structures (Figure 6a). In this stretchable SC, the customizable architectures (honeycomb-like structure, pyramid pop-up structure, living-hinge structure, etc.) could be optimized for stretchability along any axis of choice (Figure 6c). The honeycomb-like SC structure exhibited a 227.2 mF cm−2 specific capacitance which did not degrade even when it was stretched to 500% strain (Figure 6d). Remarkably, the capacitance retainment was kept at ≈98% after 10 000 stretch-and-release cycles to a maximum of 400% tensile strain (Figure 6e,f). It was further demonstrated that two honeycomb-like SCs fixed in series on an Ecoflex substrate could power an integrated strain sensor worn on an arm (Figure 6g).
As one of the most representative 1D nanomaterials, CNTs are widely used in the design of stretchable electronic devices due to their moderate surface area, porous structure, excellent electronic conductivity, and exceptional mechanical and thermal stability.[14,45,46,60,64,65] Recently, Yu et al. fabricated CNT supercapacitors by transferring the floating catalyst CVDgrown CNT to an omnidirectional prestrained silicon rubber

elastomer, demonstrating stretchability up to 200% strain in all directions and nearly identical CV curves under different strains measured at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1.[36] To improve the specific capacitance of the omnidirectionally stretchable SCs, they deposited PANI onto a buckled CNT structure. The final SC with PANI@CNT electrodes exhibited a specific capacitance of 1147 mF cm−2 at the scan rate of 10 mV s−1, more than 100 times higher than that of the bare CNT based SC. It was also found that the as-developed PANI@CNT SC had excellent mechanical stability with only ≈3% capacitance loss after 20 uniaxial stretching cycles. The materials, structure design, and electrochemical performance of the stretchable SCs developed with 1D nanomaterials are summarized in Table 1. It can be seen that thanks to its excellent properties, CNT is the most popular 1D nanomaterial used in stretchable SCs, which are not only directly utilized as SC electrodes by themselves, but also commonly hybridized with other nanomaterials to form stretchable composite electrodes such as buckled CNTs on elastomeric substrates[45] and hybrid CNT/ elastomer composites.[66]

sections.heading: 3.3. 2D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
2D nanomaterials such as graphene, metal sulfides, and transition metal carbides/nitrides (MXene) have been considered for emerging applications in various electronics, photonics, and energy storage devices due to their superior properties such as
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (8 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
high surface area, charge carrier mobility, elasticity, flexibility, and transparency.[41,67] Over the past two decades, significant progress has been achieved in the development of flexible and stretchable SCs using 2D materials, though certain challenges still remain in the production of flexible, robust SCs with optimal cycling stability as well as energy and power density at low cost. For example, Kim et al. developed a 2D re-entrant cellular structure of porous graphene/CNT networks for SC electrodes (Figure 7a).[68] The omnidirectionally stretchable electrodes were composed of vertically aligned rGO/CNT networks in a honeycomb structure which were synthesized through a directional crystallization technique. Even under a strain of 50%, the 2D auxetic cellular rGO/CNT networks could maintain their excellent conductivity performance due to a low-magnitude negative Poisson’s ratio in combination with intrinsic elasticity of the designed structure (Figure 7b). The completed SC devices possessed gravimetric, areal, and volumetric capacitance parameters (measured at a current density of 0.5 A g−1) as high as 152.4 F g−1, 2.9 F cm−2, and 29.3 F cm−3, respectively. The devices could retain 88% or 91% capacitance of their initial values after the respective applications of 100% × 100% biaxial or 100% uniaxial strain (Figure 7c,d). In addition, Li et al.[69] presented an elastic all-solid-state SC design with compact graphene/MoS2 nanocomposite electrodes and PVA/H3PO4 electrolyte fabricated via a facile pressing method, as illustrated in Figure 7e. No significant variation was observed from the CV curves at a scan rate of 0.1 V s−1 when the SC was stretched from 0 to 60% strain (Figure 7f). The galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves of the SC also exhibited little change under different tensile strains at a constant charge–discharge current of 2.0 mA (Figure 7g). With a volumetric capacitance of 19.44 F cm−3 (70.00 mF cm−2), the new SCs demonstrated 87% capacitance retention after 300 stretching cycles to 30% strain, although strains up to 60% were deemed bearable with minor performance degradation (Figure 7h). The materials and stretching strategy used, as well as the electrochemical performance and stretchability of stretchable SCs fabricated from 2D nanomaterials, are summarized in Table 2 for comparison. It can be found that the great advantages of using 2D materials like graphene for supercapacitor

applications are their high conductivity and large surface area. To further improve the energy density of graphene-based devices, one effective approach is to develop hybrid composites made with 2D graphene and conducting polymers or transition metal oxides. The availability of a large variety of van der Waals layered materials provides great chances for people to develop new 2D materials like MXene for next-generation high-performance SC electrodes.

sections.heading: 3.4. Nanomaterial Composites
sections.text:
Typically, stretchable SCs only based on carbon materials demonstrate high power density with inferior energy density and low specific capacitance due to their limitations in charge accumulation on the electrode surface, while pseudocapacitive materials such as MnO2,[70] MoS2,[71] Co3O4,[72] PANI,[73] and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS)[74] may provide superior specific capacitance and energy density due to surface redox reactions. Therefore, to develop high performance SCs, much attention has been paid
upon composite electrodes incorporating both carbon materials and pseudocapacitive materials due to the benefits of: i) simultaneous enhancement of energy density and power density;[72,75] ii) exceptional cycle stability from carbon materials; iii) higher electrical conductivity from carbon materials for electron transport; and iv) excellent capacitive properties attributed to the high capacitance of pseudocapacitive materials and high surface area of carbon materials.[24]
In this regard, Lu and co-workers developed a stretchable SC device which could survive up to 50% strain without reduction in conductivity (Figure 8a).[76] The device fabrication process involved the deposition of PANI nanofibers on a multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT)/PDMS film synthesized with water surface assistance, resulting in PANI/MWCNT/PDMS film electrodes. The final stretchable SCs demonstrated a high gravimetric capacitance of 1023 F g−1 and areal capacitance of 481 mF cm−3 measured at the scan rate of 5 mV s−1 (Figure 8b). Even after 500 cycles of stretch/release, the as-fabricated SCs possessed an impressive 95% capacitance retention (Figure 8c), alongside a decent maximum energy density of 0.15 mW h cm−3 (11 W h kg−1). Larger stretchability has been demonstrated by

1803976 (10 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
a superelastic fiber-shaped SC with two CNT/PANI composite electrodes, exhibiting a remarkable specific capacitance of 79.4 F g−1.[77] The fiber-shaped SCs had excellent performance retention after 5000 stretching cycles to 300% strain with a maximum strain tolerance exceeding 400%, highlighting again the superior physical properties achieved through the combination of EDLC and pseudocapacitive materials without compromise in the aspect of electrical performance.
Recently, Park and co-workers studied the pseudocapacitive behavior of layered MoS2 nanosheets hybridized with reduced graphene oxide (RGO), and reported that the RGO/MoS2 hybrid exhibited a specific capacitance of 206 F g−1, which is 1.7 times greater than that of 2D MoS2 (118 F g−1) and two orders of magnitude greater than that of bulk MoS2 at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1, respectively.[78] In another different work, Chen and co-workers proposed an all-solid-state SC fabricated with aligned CNTs in CNT/MoS2 hybrid electrodes,[79] where the SC device was made by utilizing CNT/MoS2 hybrids as current collectors and electrodes simultaneously, along with gel electrolyte sandwiched in the middle. After MoS2 solution was drop-coated onto CVD-grown horizontally aligned CNTs on PDMS substrate, the material surface was generated (Figure 8d–f). Despite falling short of their theoretical performance, the fabricated devices demonstrated the great potential
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (11 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
for excellent stretchability and capacitive performance attributed to SCs incorporating CNT-based composite electrodes. An excellent specific capacitance of 13.16 F cm−3 was achieved with 6.5 wt% of MoS2 in the CNT/MoS2 composite, alongside exceptional cycling stability examined over 10 000 charge–discharge cycles. The specific capacitances of stretchable SCs could remain 96% of their original values after stretched to 100% strain for 500 cycles (Figure 8h), indicating their outstanding stability. In the mechanical tests, optimal electrochemical performance was maintained as stretching was applied in the range of 0–240% with a steady rate of 3 mm min−1 (Figure 8g). To enhance the device performance in stretchability and capacitance, they further proposed the all-solid-state SC design using aligned CNT/Ag-doped PEDOT:PSS composites for electrodes and PVA-based electrolyte.[80] The fabricated all-solid-state SCs exhibited an excellent specific capacitance of 64 mF cm−2, and could maintain an astounding 98% of the initial capacitance even under a tensile strain of 480%. In addition, the SCs also showed remarkable stretching stability, retaining 90% of the optimal capacitance after 100 stretching cycles up to 400% strain (Figure 8i). Therefore, the composite materials consisting of carbon materials and metal oxides/conducting polymers can be employed in the design of electrodes for high-performance SCs, taking advantage of the large specific surface area and the super conductivity of carbon materials, and the high capacitance of metal oxides and conducting polymers. Although 3D nanostructured materials such as graphene aerogels, mesoporous carbon, and 3D nanoflowers are also showing great performance and having potential applications in stretchable SCs, we are here mainly focusing on the low-dimensional nanomaterials (0D, 1D, and 2D) in this review. Interested readers for 3D structured electrodes can refer to some recent review work on nanomaterials for supercapacitor electrodes.[24]

sections.heading: 4. Design Strategies for Stretchability
sections.text: In developing stretchable supercapacitors, a few design strategies have been employed by different researchers over the years. The several major designs include the wavy-shape (buckled or wrinkled) design, wire-shape design, textile-shape design, kirigami and origami inspired designs, and serpentine bridge-island design. In the following parts of this section, we separately review these major stretchability designs and their applications.

sections.heading: 4.1. Wavy-Shape Design
sections.text:
The wavy-shaped structure has been widely utilized in designing stretchable SCs due to its simplicity in fabrication and its capability of achieving high stretchability.[81,82] The “wavy” structures can be obtained through the relaxation of a thin layer of active materials bonded on a prestrained substrate.[61,83] In brief, the stretchable electrode films can be fabricated through the “prestrain–transfer–release” approach to assembling stretchable SCs, which usually includes three steps: i) prestrain of an elastomeric substrate; ii) transfer of active electrode materials onto the prestrained substrate; and iii) release of the prestrain in the substrate. For example, Niu et al. directly transferred SWCNT films possessing continuous reticulate architecture to a prestrained PDMS substrate to form stretchable SCs (Figure 9a,b).[65] The resulting devices demonstrated consistent electrochemical performance under different strains (Figure 9c). Nyquist plots showed nearly the same performance for the SCs in the high frequency domain under varying strains (Figure 9d). The similar diameters and Z′ values indicated that the interior contact resistance was not affected
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (12 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com

www.small-journal.com
by the applied strains. Remarkably, the specific capacitances of the stretchable SCs are nearly unchanged over 1000 cycles (Figure 9e), indicating the excellent electrochemical stability of the stretchable SCs.
As depicted in Figure 2f, Zang et al. utilized the same method to fabricate stretchable SCs with CG-paper on elastomer substrates.[40] The SCs based on the CG-paper electrodes exhibited unprecedented stretchability with linear and areal strains respectively attaining 300% and 800%, as well as an exceptional specific capacitance value of 196 F g−1 which experienced little deterioration after 1000 stretch/release cycles. Peng and coworkers also developed a procedure for fabricating marvelously stretchable SCs with excellent electrochemical performance through the addition of a nitrogen-doped core–sheath carbon nanotube array for use in elastic electrodes (Figure 9f).[84] As shown in Figure 9g, the stretchable SCs demonstrated a stable specific capacitance at 31.1 mF cm−2, of which 98.9% could be maintained after applying a strain of 400%, while 96%
was preserved after 1000 stretching cycles when reaching a maximum strain of 200%.[84]

sections.heading: 4.2. Wire-Shape Design
sections.text:
The wire-shape design has also been harnessed to fabricate highly stretchable SCs.[85–88] Although wire-shaped SCs may have great potential applications in smart textiles, they encounter notable challenges in simultaneously achieving high electrochemical performance and mechanical stretchability.[85] The first attempt of a wire-shape design for obtaining both high electrochemical performance and high stretchability was demonstrated by using spinnable CNT arrays grown by a CVD method.[86] As shown in Figure 10a–c, a highly stretchable, fiber-shaped SC with a coaxial structure was fabricated through aligned CNT sheets enwrapping an elastic fiber along with alternating layers of gel electrolyte. The fiber-shaped SC
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (13 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
yielded a specific capacitance of 19.2 F g−1 and could maintain its performance well when subjected to applied strains up to 75% (Figure 15d,e). About 95% of the initial device capacitance remained after 100 cycles of stretching to 75% strain.[86] In further work, a volumetric capacitance of 409.4 F cm−3, approximately 33 times that of the previous CNT-based fiber SC, was achieved through the integration of a novel MnO2/ oxidized CNT hybrid fiber synthesized via two simple solutionbased procedures.[87] An elastic fiber SC incorporating two such hybrid fibers by means of a prestraining-then-buckling procedure perfectly combined this exceptional volumetric capacitance with electrochemical and mechanical stability sufficient to endure cyclic tensile strain up to 40%.[87] The volumetric energy density and power density of this SC reached 14.2 mWh cm−3 and 6250 mW cm−3, respectively, superior to most of the previously reported fiber-shaped SCs. In the meantime, higher stretchability performance of up to 100% tensile strain was reported with asymmetric stretchable SCs fabricated with MnO2/CNT hybrid fiber as the positive electrode, aerogel CNT fiber as the negative electrode, and KOH/PVA as the electrolyte.[88] The specific capacitance of 157.53 µF cm−1 was measured at the scan rate of 50 mV s−1.[88] This impressive electrochemical performance combined with the remarkable mechanical stretchability made the wire-shape SCs suitable for their eventual integration with smart textile applications.[88]

sections.heading: 4.3. Origami or Kirigami Inspired Design
sections.text:
Origami and kirigami are two historical forms of art, where origami refers to the folding of paper while kirigami refers to the combination of paper folding and paper cutting.[89,90] The concepts of origami and kirigami have been utilized for designing stretchable electronics and energy devices.[91–93] These approaches provide a facile path to fabricate a stacked or folded device without expanding the area or complicating
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (14 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
the fabrication process, thus enabling the high stretchability of the device, which can be tuned based on the design requirement by using different kinds of configurations. For example, in one recent work by Nam et al.,[91] an origami-type foldable structure consisting of periodically isolated electrodes (IEs) and sectionalized electrolytes was utilized to fabricate all-solidstate supercapacitors, which are essential for achieving an increased potential window without an upper limit. As demonstrated in Figure 11a–c, the zigzag origami-type structure can accommodate very high stability stretching.[91] On the other hand, Song et al. also developed a foldable micro-SC with the help of the Miura origami pattern consisting of parallelograms with smaller areas.[94] The folded micro-SCs showed a ≈4.3 times increase in areal capacitance with improved energy densities.[94]
Similarly, kirigami can also be used for achieving high stretchability for novel emerging electronics.[92,93,95] The rationally designed cuts of kirigami pattern are able to release strain and enhance deformability throughout the structure with the facilitation of segment-level rotation, bending, and twisting. As presented in Figure 11d, Lin and co-workers demonstrated a kirigami-inspired highly stretchable micro-SC patch (reversible stretchability >282.5%, with <2% change in capacitance
retention) with high areal-coverage of functional electronic components (76.2%).[92] The kirigami design enabled the micro-SC to achieve far greater stretchability than the state-ofthe-art stretchable SCs using the accordion construct, and have superior areal-coverage in comparison to the reported stretchable SCs with the island-bridge construct (Figure 11e).[92] This new strategy paves an avenue for developing stretchable microsupercapacitors in future flexible, stretchable, and wearable systems. In addition, kirigami-based designs have also been employed in the fabrication of stretchable batteries and were demonstrated to be able to bring exceptional electrochemical and mechanical performance for lithium ion batteries (LIBs) produced through standardized battery manufacturing.[93] In one example, the LIBs with kirigami designs have proven to be capable of powering a smart watch after integration and achieved a great stretchability over 150%.[93]

sections.heading: 4.4. Textile-Shape Design
sections.text:
A textile is a flexible and permeable material which is typically woven from natural or synthetic fibers such as polyester, cotton,
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (15 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
or yarn into a flexible network, exhibiting remarkable stretchability.[96,97] The advancement of research on innovative textiles has altered the fabric industry into a potential medium for many large-scale electronics applications. Recent prototypes of textile and fiber SCs were fabricated through the application of thin film layers on textile surfaces or the direct chemical modification of fibers, showing the potential for textile-based energy storage applications.[98] In one instance, 200% stretching strain was achieved for a textile structure, which consisted of a tricot weave in diagonal directions with inelastic polyester yarns determining the basic architectural framework and elastic spandex yarns woven around the loops of polyester yarn in a repetitive zigzag design (Figure 12a,b).[99] Excellent mechanical stability was observed from the CV curves shown in Figure 12c for stretchable SCs with the textile alongside MWCNTs, in which little difference in CV curves was seen regardless of the presence of dynamic strains. Also, in the biaxial stretching testing, a capacitance of 35 F g−1 at 0.25 A g−1 was retained to a high degree under the strain of 50% × 50% (Figure 12d).
A great variety of yarns with different mechanical and electrical properties can be found in the textile industry, potentially resulting in the development of a diverse array of yarn-based SCs. An emphasis on stretchability was seen in the large-scale yarn-based SCs fabricated by Hu and co-workers,[100] which included wearable urethane fiber core spun yarn (UY) electrodes possessing intrinsically excellent stretchability as a platform for hosting electrocapacitive PPy and conductive CNTs (Figure 12e,f). The yarn supercapacitors fabricated by twisting two of the PPy@CNTs@UY electrodes together sandwiched by a PVA/H3PO4 gel electrolyte showed a high areal capacitance of 69 mF cm−2 measured at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1, and thanks to the high stretchability of the electrodes, this capacitance
could be maintained by more than 85% of its initial value after 1000 cyclic stretches from 0% to 40% strain (Figure 12g–i).[100] The good capacitive properties were believed to originate from the synergistic effect of the conducting CNT backbone on the yarn and PPy conductive wrapping layer, which improved the electrical conductivity and pseudocapacitive performance simultaneously.[100]

sections.heading: 4.5. Serpentine Bridge-Island Design
sections.text:
Serpentine electrode interconnection structures are another strategy that has been employed in stretchable SCs for achieving a high degree of stretchability.[90,101] Figure 13a–d shows stretchable SCs consisting of planar SWCNT electrodes and ionic liquidbased triblock copolymer electrolyte, in which the functional components reside on the island, while the serpentine interconnects form the bridge.[102,103] As shown in Figure 13e, the stretchable SCs under the charging state at 3 V were demonstrated to be able to light an LED when discharging under bent (with a bending radius of 2.5 cm) or stretched state (30% strain).[102] In this design, under stretching, the serpentine interconnects (low effective stiffness) deform to provide the stretchability, while the rigid islands (high effective stiffness) remain almost undeformed to ensure the mechanical integrity of functional materials. It should be noted that depending on the combination of structural design and fabrication process chosen, the serpentine interconnects may be fully bonded, partially bonded, or completely nonbonded to the elastomeric substrate.[90] Zhang et al. systematically studied the effects of key geometric and material parameters on the elastic stretchability and the enhancements enabled by the prestrain strategy.[104] In another demonstration,
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (16 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
Bandodkar et al. presented a unique elastic ‘‘island-bridge’’ configuration for wearable biofuel cells which employed a framework of serpentine lithographically patterned Au interconnects in combination with a dense, screen printed CNT-based bioanode/cathode array.[105] The resulting 2D Au serpentine interconnects linking the electrodes and contact pads yielded a high degree of stretchability without compromise in stability. As presented above, though all those different kinds of design strategies can be used to make stretchable SCs, each of them has their own advantages and disadvantages. Thus, a few factors should be considered when determining a suitable method for fabricating stretchable SCs, including active materials used, electrochemical performance needed, cost of fabrication, and requirements in application. Among
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (17 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
the design configurations, the wavy-shape design is a very straightforward and simple method that can be implemented easily and used by a wide range of materials. However, the maximum stretchability of this design is mainly constrained by the elastomer substrates. This method is also challengeable for scalable fabrication and potential integration with other stretchable devices. Moreover, the active material for an electrode layer should be thin enough so as to avoid cracking or delamination during the cyclic deformations. As for the wire-shape design, it has the remarkable advantage of easier integration with textile and wearable electronics. However, the fiber form and structure requirement would increase the process cost and limits active material choices. The electrochemical performance of the fiber-shaped design is also relatively lower and pretty challenging to be improved with the mechanical performance simultaneously. The textile-shape design is an extension of the wire-shape design. While the textile-shape design is the most suitable strategy for scalable production of stretchable SCs, the electrochemical performance should be further improved to meet the energy and power density requirements of large-scale stretchable electronics. On the other hand, the kirigami and origami inspired designs represent novel design alternatives for achieving extreme stretchability of supercapacitors. The stretchability can be programmed by the designed patterns of origami or kirigami. The main disadvantages of such designs are the complexity involved from intensive design and the cost induced in the fabrication process. The serpentine bridgeisland design has been widely used for stretchable electronics by Rogers and co-workers.[90] Compared to other design strategies, this approach facilitates the integration of electronic components with the power sources. The modular design in this method also supplies the possibility of
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (18 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
employing commercial nondeformable supercapacitors, batteries, and other electronics to form multifunctional stretchable electronics systems. Nevertheless, the low stretchability alongside the complex fabrication process and high cost are the drawbacks of this design strategy.

sections.heading: 5. All-Solid-State Electrolytes for Stretchable Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Electrolytes with good mechanical performance, high ionic conductivity, superior stability, and low cost are highly desirable for assembling stretchable SCs.[30,49,106–109] Compared with liquid electrolytes, all-solid-state gel electrolytes become more attractive due to their properties of compactness, reliability, and capability to minimize the risks of liquid leakage as well as their excellent ionic conductivity (10−4–10−1 S cm−1) under ambient conditions.[30] These solid-state electrolytes typically consist of a polymeric framework (e.g., PVA and poly (ethylene oxide)) and an electrolytic salt (e.g., H2SO4, H3PO4, KOH, and LiClO4) dissolved in an organic/aqueous solvent filling in the framework.[108] Stretchable SCs incorporating a highly elastic H3PO4/PVA polymer electrolyte can be fabricated by tuning the polymer molecular weight and weight ratio to H3PO4 for optimization of conductivity and mechanical performance.[49] The as-fabricated SCs have demonstrated remarkable electrochemical stability with 81% retainment of the initial capacitance after 1000 cycles of stretching to 30% strain.[49]
Nevertheless, most hydrogel polymer electrolytes used in stretchable SCs are mixed solutions, resulting in poor structural integrity and mechanical strength. To solve this issue, Wei and co-workers proposed a chemically cross-linked PVAH2SO4 hydrogel film of high stretchability and ionic conductivity using glutaraldehyde dilute solution,[110] which demonstrated an ionic conductivity of 0.082 S cm−1 and stretchability of up to 300% strain. Recently, Zhi and co-workers developed a multifunctional polyelectrolyte of polyacrylic acid (PAA) dual cross-linked by hydrogen bonding and vinyl hybrid silica nanoparticles (VSNP-PAA) to realize high stretchability and excellent self-healing ability.[107] By paving highly flexible PPy/CNT paper electrodes on the prestretching of the PAA electrolyte, the assembled supercapacitor can be stretched up to 600% with enhanced performance. In another work by Ha and coworkers,[111] a poly(methyl methacrylate)–propylene carbonate– lithium perchlorate (PMMA–PC–LiClO4) gel electrolyte was successfully developed and exhibited excellent stability in air for more than two weeks. The CNT/Mn3O4 based micro SCs using this gel electrolyte exhibited a 30 times higher energy density than that of graphene-based micro SCs with PVA-H3PO4 gel electrolyte. Similarly, Tang et al. presented a stretchable SC using Na2SO4–anionic polyurethane acrylates/polyacrylamide (aPUA/PAAM) hydrogel electrolyte with intrinsic stretchability over 1000%.[112] The strong stickiness and high ionic conductivity of the hydrogel electrolyte result in good electrochemical performances of the SC under large strains, delivering a specific capacitance of 478.6 mF cm−2 at 0.5 mA cm−2 and 91.5% retention of its initial capacity after 3000 stretching cycles up to 150% strain.[112] In another pioneer work, ionic liquid was also employed as electrolyte with a high voltage window up
to 3 V, though the disadvantages of flammability and toxicity did exist.[113] More detailed review on the gel electrolyte used in flexible and stretchable SCs for different applications can be found in other literature.[109]

sections.heading: 6. Substrates for Stretchable Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Robust stretchable substrates are essentially important for developing reliable stretchable SCs that can maintain their integration under large deformations.[90,114] Besides stretchability, desired properties for the stretchable substrate also include high resistance to chemicals and good stability for thermal and radiation loadings, as well as excellent surface properties and adhesion with nanomaterials. It should be noticed that although most of the polymer substrates in stretchable supercapacitors only acted as supporting substrates, some carbon-based substrates played two roles in the devices, i.e., serving as both substrate and active electrode.[115] Currently a variety of stretchable substrates, including VHB (3M Inc. USA),[40] PDMS,[116] polyurethane (PU),[117] thermoplastic polyurethanes (TPU),[118] and thermoplastic elastomers (TPE)[118] are commonly used due to their superior performance in accommodating large strain deformations and significant shape change like bending, twisting, folding, and stretching. These stretchable substrates also demonstrated good stability in weak acids and alkali, and even high transparency.[30]
Meanwhile, elastic threads, carbon clothes/fibers, and yarnbased wire substrates are also fabricated for 1D wearable devices, typically woven into textiles and fabrics that can sustain a certain level of strains.[30,88,115] Additionally, for wire/fibershaped designs as illustrated in Section 4.2, a large number of wire/fiber SCs with various electrode materials can be fabricated using either coaxial or twisted structures and different types of wire-like integrated systems have been designed for wearable electronics applications.[88] Different from the filmsubstrate design, the stretchability in these kinds of devices is mainly contributed by the helix or spring structures. Although stainless-steel mesh has also been used for stretchable substrates, it usually has the limitation of low strain accommodation (≈20%) and lacks the tactile comfort necessary for wearable electronics.[119] A summary for the widely used substrate materials in their properties and applications is presented in Table 3.

sections.heading: 7.1. Stretchable Asymmetric SCs
sections.text:
Owing to their inferior energy density in comparison to batteries, SCs are usually used as backup power sources supporting batteries for electric cars. Related research has shown that the energy density of SCs may be raised to a certain extent through increasing the operating voltage window using all-solid-state asymmetric SCs with dissimilar electrode materials.[120,121] By maximizing the difference in potential windows between the positive and negative electrode materials, a high operation voltage and energy density may be achieved.[21,107,122] With this approach, Chou and co-workers
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (19 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
developed a hybrid core–sheath stretchable asymmetric fibershaped SC, in which CNT@MnO2 fiber was employed as the positive electrode and core fiber, while CNT@PPy film was wrapped outside the core fiber as the negative electrode with gel electrolyte in between (Figure 14a–d).[121] By overtwisting the fiber, a stretchable helical and asymmetric SC was formed, which exhibited a specific capacitance of 60.435 mF cm−2 at a 10 mV s−1 scan rate, and an impressive energy density of 18.88 µWh cm−2 after factoring in the extended 1.5 V potential window (Figure 14e,f). Although there was an initial loss of the capacitive performance in the first 200 stretching cycles, over 80% of the capacitance remained even after 5000 cycles at both 0% and 20% strains (Figure 14g).
Similarly, Zhang and co-workers developed hierarchically structured, high capacitance MnO2@PEDOT:PSS@oxidized CNT fibers (MnO2@PEDOT:PSS@OCNTF) as positive electrodes and flower-shaped MoS2 nanosheets@CNTF (MoS2@ CNTF) as negative electrodes to manufacture asymmetric stretchable SCs capable of operation at 1.8 V (Figure 14h).[123] There was little change observed in the charge–discharge curves under different strains less than 100% (Figure 14i), while the stretchable fiber-shaped SCs demonstrated the highest specific capacitance (278.6 mF cm−2) and energy density (125.37 µWh cm−2) reported to date (Figure 14k). Furthermore, the device has also exhibited superior stretchability, with a capacitance retention of 92% after 3000 cycles of stretching to a strain of 100% (Figures 14j and 15l). It can be seen that moving beyond hybrid electrodes, asymmetric stretchable SCs incorporating pseudocapacitive and double layer electrodes could be promising alternatives to break the energy density limitation of traditional electrochemical capacitors. In addition, the selection of appropriate electrode materials and the design of unique hybrid electrodes are key factors in realizing the full potential of hybrid electrode materials and hybrid asymmetric stretchable SCs.

sections.heading: 7.2. Stretchable Micro SCs
sections.text:
With the increasing attention in portable and wearable electronics, tremendous efforts have been devoted to the development
of miniature but powerful energy storage devices.[124] Micro-SCs are able to quickly respond to ions and electrons, thus yielding power densities far superior to those in standard batteries and SCs.[125] In addition, high performance micro-SCs can be designed and integrated with additional functions able to endow them with impressive properties, including flexibility, stretchability, and lightness of weight.[126] One recent example is a stretchable microSC formed by wavy graphene microribbons suspended on a tripod-structured PDMS substrate (Figure 15a–c).[127] This novel architecture could dramatically reduce the stress endured by the electrode during stretching through the fabrication of wrinkled electrodes suspended on the stretchable substrate in place of a direct attachment. As a result, very little change was observed in the capacitive behavior of the device after applying a strain of 100%, and a retainment of ≈92% of the original capacitance was recorded after 5000 stretching cycles. Remarkably, after charging, the micro-SCs were capable of lighting the LCD of a calculator under 100% strain, again affirming the potential applications of stretchable micro-SCs in portable electronics emphasizing flexibility or stretchability.
Recently, Wang and co-workers developed a simple method to fabricate 3D networks of porous graphene via direct laser induction on polyimide sheets (Figure 15d).[128] After transferring laser-induced graphene (LIG) onto silicone rubber, transparent, flexible, and stretchable in-plane micro-SCs can be acquired with a remarkable elasticity capable of accommodating 400% strain, as shown in Figure 15e. Through doping of the LIG electrodes with nitrogen and additional coating with conductive PEDOT, the micro-SCs could reach capacitance as high as 720 µF cm−2 at a discharge current of 75 µA cm−2. In another work, encapsulation was utilized to successfully fabricate wearable and waterproof arrays of stacked planar micro-SCs,[129] in which MWCNT electrodes were spray-coated on Au film alongside a UV-patternable ion-gel electrolyte for all-solid-state devices. The devices operated normally in water even under different kinds of deformations (bending, winding, stretching, and twisting), demonstrating no change in the brightness of
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (20 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
an integrated LED (Figure 15f). The CV curves under large deformations also exhibited very stable rectangular shapes, without noticeable changes in capacitance (Figure 15g). It was also demonstrated that about 88% of the initial capacitance was retained after 2000 cycles of repetitive stretching to 30% strain, and the capacitance showed little change when the stretchable micro-SCs were immersed in water (Figure 15h),[129] indicating perfect encapsulation that enabled the device to operate well in water for a long period.

sections.heading: 7.3. Stretchable Multifunctional SCs and Their System Integration
sections.text:
Apart from the pursuit of superior electrochemical and mechanical performance, there exists increasing interest in developing stretchable SCs with multifunctionality, including self-powering capability, electrochromism, sensing, photodetection, and so on. One attempt was to use electrochromic PANI on a wrinkled CNT sheet for the electrode active material and
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (21 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
capacity sensing component (Figure 16a,b).[12] The specific capacitance of the as-fabricated PANI/CNT stretchable SC could reach 308.4 F g−1 at the scan rate of 1 A g−1, which is decent among most stretchable SCs reported. Additionally, the SCs from the PANI/CNT sheet could be bent, twisted, and stretched to a strain of up to 100% with favorable capacitance retention (Figure 16c). More interestingly, owing to the different oxidation states of PANI at different potentials, the color of the SC can be changed from blue at 1 V to yellow at −1 V by switching the applied potential (Figure 16a,b). The chromatic character could serve as a dynamic sensor of the stored energy in the stretchable SCs.
Most recently, stretchable SCs capable of self-powering and strain sensing have been developed. For instance, by integrating a micro-supercapacitor (MSC) array, a strain sensor, and Si solar cells onto a deformable elastomer substrate via serpentine interconnections, Jeong and co-workers demonstrated a stretchable, self-powered, continually operated, and skin
attachable strain sensing system (Figure 16d).[130] The system had a capacitance of 5 mF cm−2 with 100% capacitance retention after 1000 biaxial stretching cycles with strains up to 30%. The detection of wrist bending was demonstrated under light illumination without external power supply. It is noted that the integration of nanomaterial-based biofuel cells with supercapacitors will also offer an alternative method of self-powering for future wearable and medical devices.[11,131]
Another important direction is to expand the stretchable SCs from 2D shaped electrodes to 3D electrodes. Traditional stretchable SCs, with thin electrodes and 2D shapes, have limited specific areal capacitance and are incompatible with 3D wearable electronics. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop 3D stretchable SCs with higher mass loading and customizable shapes. For example, recently Lv et al. developed a 3D stretchable SC with an expandable honeycomb structure composed of porous PPy/ black phosphorus oxide composites electrodeposited on CNT films, demonstrating an outstanding specific areal capacitance
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (22 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
of 7.35 F cm−2 and a 95% capacitance retention even under 2000% tensile strain after 10 000 stretch-and-release cycles.[10] Meanwhile, other functionalities such as power-controlling and photodetection have been demonstrated in flexible SCs,[132] though not yet in stretchable SCs. It should be expected that integrating stretchable SCs together with other electronic components of multiple functions will be a promising research field for future emerging electronics.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions and Perspectives
sections.text:
In this review, with a focus on stretchable SCs from low-dimensional nanomaterials, we have highlighted the advances and progresses that have been achieved in recent years, including the electrode materials, structure design, and fabrication process, as well as the electrochemical and mechanical performance and stability of devices. We first discussed the three major categories of stretchable SCs and then presented the representative work in developing stretchable electrodes with 0D, 1D, and 2D nanomaterials. Next, we emphasized the design strategies utilized for achieving the stretchability of the devices, including the wavy-shape design, wire-shape design, textileshape design, origami-shape design, kirigami-shape design, and serpentine bridge-island design. Finally, we discussed the newest developments alongside future directions and outlook in the field of stretchable SC development and manufacturing.
Despite the significant progress in the design and fabrication of stretchable SCs, grand challenges are hindering the realization of their practical applications on large scales, and many factors affecting their electrochemical and mechanical performance remain unexplored. The primary challenges include: i) development of novel materials with superior electrochemical
and mechanical performance for stretchable electrodes; ii) simultaneous enhancement of the energy density and power density of stretchable devices; iii) development of stretchable solid electrolytes with ionic conductivity comparable to liquid electrolytes currently used; and iv) invention of feasible, costeffective fabrication approaches to spin out stretchable SCs from lab research to commercial products.
In the further development of stretchable SCs, there are a few issues that should be addressed. First, the relationship between the ion transport, structure, and capacitive performance of electrode materials should be thoroughly examined to develop optimal stretchable SC designs. The discovery of novel composite electrode materials will bring substantial opportunities to improve the electrochemical performance of stretchable SCs. Also, to increase active material loading in stretchable SCs but without compromising their electrochemical and mechanical properties will be helpful for enhancing the total energy capacity of SCs in practical applications, especially for smallfootprint devices. Second, high performance all-solid-state gel electrolytes should be designed for larger operation voltage, superior ion-transporting properties, excellent interface with the electrode materials, and exceptional stability with advanced packaging. As such, it is desirable to use an electrolyte with a wider voltage window to raise the SC cell voltage, and thus the energy density. Third, the invention of facile, highly accurate, and sustainable manufacturing technologies is also highly desirable for fabricating stretchable SCs in the future. The direct deposition of SC electrodes on substrate should be explored via additive manufacturing techniques applicable to a wide range of low-dimensional nanomaterials and substrates, instead of indirect transfer or conversion of a pre-prepared thin film. Further effort should be paid to the exploration of new stretchable substrate materials with enhanced mechanical
Small 2018, 14, 1803976
1803976 (23 of 26)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
properties, in particular, the self-healable substrates with long lifespans that are strongly desired in certain applications. In addition, suitable encapsulation technology is crucial for the integration of stretchable SCs and the broad applications of SCs in complex environments. Beyond protecting electrolytes from deterioration due to solvent evaporation or oxidation, encapsulation also allows the SCs to be used for underwater applications. Finally, the integration of the stretchable SCs with other electronics and energy devices such as solar cells, sensors, lithium-ion batteries, and nanogenerators in smart, stretchable, and multifunctional devices perhaps represents another important developmental direction. For example, through the coupling of stretchable triboelectric nanogenerators and stretchable SCs, novel self-charging power systems may be designed, which can harvest and store environmental mechanical energy and human kinetic energy.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/smll.201803976 wearable devices,[1,2] sensitive robotic skin,[3] electronic papers,[4] soft surgical tools,[5] electronic imaging devices,[5] in vivo health monitors,[3] as well as various collapsible gadgets[6] has attracted widespread attention upon flexible and stretchable electronics with a combination of advanced electrical performance with robust mechanical properties such as stretchability, foldability, twistability, flexibility, and durability.[7,8] In particular, device stretchability is highly desirable for wearable electronics due to the inevitable deformation (strain) generated in human skin and human body activity. As essential components of stretchable electronics systems, energy conversion and storage devices should be capable of sustaining their performance when subjected to the large strains that may be experienced by the highly stretchable electronics in various applications. The consistency of stretchability in both electronics and energy devices becomes the key to the successful integration of a combined self-powered stretchable system in wearable electronics applications. To date, significant effort and progress have been made in developing stretchable energy devices such as batteries, supercapacitors (SCs), and solar cells.[9–13] Although batteries are typically favored among power sources for electronic devices due to their superior power density and energy Supercapacitors (SCs) have shown great potential for mobile energy storage technology owing to their long-term durability, electrochemical stability, structural simplicity, as well as exceptional power density without much compromise in the energy density and cycle life parameters. As a result, stretchable SC devices have been incorporated in a variety of emerging electronics applications ranging from wearable electronic textiles to microrobots to integrated energy systems. In this review, the recent progress and achievements in the field of stretchable SCs enabled by low-dimensional nanomaterials such as polypyrrole, carbon nanotubes, and graphene are presented. First, the three major categories of stretchable supercapacitors are discussed: double-layer supercapacitors, pseudo-supercapacitors, and hybrid supercapacitors. Then, the representative progress in developing stretchable electrodes with low-dimensional (0D, 1D, and 2D) nanomaterials is described. Next, the design strategies enabling the stretchability of the devices, including the wavy-shape design, wire-shape design, textile-shape design, kirigami-shape design, origami-shape design, and serpentine bridgeisland design are emphasized, with the aim of improving the electrochemical performance under the complex stretchability conditions that may be encountered in practical applications. Finally, the newest developments, major challenges, and outlook in the field of stretchable SC development and manufacturing are discussed. Stretchable Supercapacitors
